mankind, than the united achievements of ancient art and
genius.
For what, then, do we contend, when we maintain that the
sciences should not bo cultivated to tho exclusion, or even the

the sciences should not supersede the belles lettres, as they are
the best foundation on which to erect the lofty superstructure

doubtless will, wherever else the attempt may be made to discard classical learning, to an abandonment of the former theory on the subject, and a restoration to the classics of all their

studied in childhood. At how early an age, do we learn, almost
as by instinct, our mother tongue! Subjects requiring strong
